questions.text: A young man has right-sided hearing loss following an accident. On otoscopic examination, the right tympanic membrane was normal. Pure tone audiogram shows conductive hearing loss of 54 dB in the right ear. Which of the following will be the likely tympanometry finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Conductive hearing loss of 54 dB implies that the hearing loss is due to ossicular chain disruption with an intact TM. Type A tympanogram is seen in such cases.

Tympanometry:

  • It is based on a simple principle,i.e. when a sound strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected.
  • A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more of the sound energy than a compliant one.
  • By changing the pressures in a sealed external auditory canal and then measuring the reflected sound energy, it is possible to find the compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system and thus find the healthy or diseased status of the middle ear.
  • By charting the compliance of the tympano-ossicular system against various pressure changes, different types of graphs are called

Types of Tympanogram:

Type A: Normal tympanogram.

Type As: Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure. Seen in fixation of ossicles, e.g. otosclerosis or malleus fixation. Option A ruled out.

Type Ad: High compliance at or near ambient pressure.Seen in ossicular discontinuity or a thin and lax tympanic membrane.

Type B: A flat or dome-shaped graph. No change in compliance with pressure changes. Seen in middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane. Option C ruled out.

Type C: Maximum compliance occurs with negative pressure over 100 mm H2O. Seen in retracted tympanic membrane and may show some fluid in the middle ear. Option D ruled out.

questions.text: What type of tympanogram is given in the picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Type C curve is on the negative pressure side and is seen in Eustachian tube blockage. Type B is a Flat Tympanogram seen in glue ear or a perforated eardrum.

Types of Tympanogram:

Type A: Normal tympanogram.

Type As: Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure. Seen in fixation of ossicles, e.g. otosclerosis or malleus fixation. Option A ruled out.

Type Ad: High compliance at or near ambient pressure.Seen in ossicular discontinuity or a thin and lax tympanic membrane. Option D ruled out.

Type B: A flat or dome-shaped graph. No change in compliance with pressure changes. Seen in middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane, and even in perforation. Option B ruled out.

Type C: Maximum compliance occurs with negative pressure over 100 mm H2O. Seen in retracted tympanic membrane and may show some fluid in the middle ear.

questions.text: Which type of audiogram is seen in the early stage of Meniere's disease
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In Meniere's disease, there is Sensorineural Hearing Loss. In the early stages, lower frequencies are affected. So there is a rising audiogram.
  • Later, with the progression of the disease, higher frequencies also get involved. This leads to a flat or falling audiogram.
  • Presbycusis has sloping audiograms as age causes high-frequency hearing loss in early stages in both ears. Option A ruled out.
  • A dip at 4000 Hz in the AC and BC curve in the audiogram is suggestive of noise-induced hearing loss. This is called an acoustic dip. Option C ruled out.
  • A dip at 2000 Hz in the BC curve is seen in Otosclerosis(Carhart's Notch). Option D ruled out.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient presenting with a hearing loss on the left side was subjected to audiometry. His audiogram is shown below.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the above audiogram, both AC and BC are poor, suggestive of SNHL.

Audiogram:

  • An audiometer is an electronic device that produces pure tones, the intensity of which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps.
  • Usually, air conduction thresholds are measured for tones of 125, 250, 500, 1000, 2000, 4000 and 8000 Hz and bone conduction thresholds for 250, 500, 1000, 2000 and 4000 Hz.
  • The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing impairment at that frequency. It is charted in the form of a graph called an audiogram.
  • The threshold of bone conduction is a measure of cochlear function. The difference in the thresholds of air and bone conduction (A-B gap) is a measure of the degree of conductive deafness.
  • It may be noted that the audiometer is so calibrated that the hearing of a normal person, both for air and bone conduction, is at 0 dB, and there is no A-B gap, while tuning fork tests normally show AC > BC.

Interpretation of Audiogram:

  • Normal - both AC & BC are within in 25dB range. (Option C ruled out)
  • CHL - AC is poor, BC is normal. AB gap (+). The hallmark of CHL is the AB Gap. (Option B and D ruled out)
  • SNHL - Both AC, BC are poor.
  • The AB gap should be a minimum of 15dB to be significant to call it CHL.

questions.text: Interpret the given audiogram and tick the appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above Audiometry shows that bone conduction is better than air conduction with an air-bone gap suggestive of Bilateral conductive hearing loss.

The characteristics of conductive hearing loss are:

  • Negative Rinne test, i.e. BC > AC.
  • Weber lateralized to the poorer ear.
  • Normal absolute bone conduction.
  • Low frequencies affected more.
  • Audiometry shows that bone conduction is better than air conduction with an air-bone gap. The greater the air-bone gap, more is the conductive loss.

A 50-year-old male patient presenting with a hearing loss complaint was subjected to audiometry. His audiogram is shown below.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above audiometry graph shows a notch at 4000 Hz in both AC and BC curves. This is typically seen in noise-induced hearing Loss.
  • The dip is known as the Acoustic dip and is seen in the beginning stages of NIHL.

Explanation of other options:

Otosclerosis(Option B):

  • Typically causes low-frequency conductive hearing loss, often with a Carhart notch at 2-kHz in bone conduction, not high-frequency notches. It is due to the interference with the transmission of bone-conducted sound due to an increase in ossicular inertia.
  • The notch disappears after stapes surgery. Middle earbone-conducted at 2000 Hz, so the notch comes at this frequency.

Ossicular dislocation(Option C): (trauma or chronic ear disease) leads to conductive hearing loss, not this high-frequency sensorineural pattern.

Meniere's disease(Option D): usually shows a rising or flat sensorineural loss, more pronounced in low frequencies, and fluctuates with vertigo episodes

questions.text: Hennebert's sign is a false-positive fistula test when there is no evidence of middle ear disease causing fistula of the horizontal semicircular canal. It is typically seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hennebert's Sign is typically seen in Congenital Syphilis.
  • Congenital syphilis is of two types: the early form, manifesting at the age of 2 and the late form, manifesting at the age of 8-20 years.

Syphilitic involvement of the inner ear can cause:

  • Sudden and sensorial hearing loss, which may be unilateral or bilateral. The latter is usually symmetrical in high frequencies or is a flat type.
  • Meniere's syndrome with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus and aural fullness-a picture simulating Meniere's disease.
  • Hennebert's sign. A positive fistula sign in the absence of a fistula. This is due to fibrous adhesions between the stapes footplate and the membranous labyrinth.
  • Tullio phenomenon, in which loud sounds produce vertigo.

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis of otosyphilis can be made by other clinical evidence, such as congenital syphilis (interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson's teeth, saddle nose, nasal septal perforation and frontal bossing) and the laboratory tests.
  • Fluorescent treponema-absorption test (FTA-ABS) and venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) or rapid plasma reagin (RPR) tests from CSF are useful to establish the diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Treatment of otosyphilis includes i.v.Penicillin, steroids.

Explanation of other options:

Acoustic Neuroma(Option B):

  • Tumour of the vestibular nerve
  • No fistula, no pressure sensitivity, not associated with Hennebert's sign

Labyrinthine Fistula(Option C):

  • True bony defect (e.g., from cholesteatoma)
  • Causes a true positive fistula test, not a false positive, so not Hennebert's sign

Otosclerosis(Option D):

  • Fixation of the stapes in the oval window
  • Causes hearing loss only, no vestibular symptoms or pressure-induced vertigo, Fistula test negative, so not Hennebert's sign.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is the initial test for neonatal screening of hearing in a healthy newborn?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

OAE requires no active participation, making it ideal for newborns. It is a non-invasive, quick, and highly sensitive.

OAE(Otoacoustic Emissions):

Principal:

  • We give sound to the ear, and then we record echoes from the Outer Hair Cell (OHC) of the cochlea.
  • These echoes are called Otoacoustic Emissions.
  • If echoes are recorded, it means the cochlea is working normally.

OAE is of 3 types, depending on the number of sound stimuli used:

  • O stimulus - it is called spontaneous OAE. (SOAE)
  • 1 stimulus - it is called Transient evoked OAE (TEOAE)
  • 2 stimuli it is called Distortion product OAE (DPOAE).
  • TEOAE are most commonly used in practice

Ideal hearing screening investigation in:

  • Neonatal Hearing Screening - OAE
  • Meningitis baby or NICU baby (high-risk baby ) - BERA

OAE device:

The zoomed-in picture of the Ear Probe:

Explanation of other options:

Automated Auditory Brainstem Response (AABR)(Option A):

  • Often used as a follow-up test if OAE is failed.
  • Also used in NICU babies or those at high risk.
  • More detailed but not the initial screening in healthy newborns.

Spontaneous Otoacoustic Emissions(Option B):

  • Sounds emitted without an external stimulus.
  • Not typically used for clinical screening due to variability.

Pure Tone Audiometry(Option D):

  • Requires patient cooperation, which is not possible in newborns.
  • Used in older children and adults.

questions.text: Identify the investigation being carried out in the given picture
questions.solution:
Electrocochleography(EcochG):

  • It is a special investigation used to diagnose Meniere's disease.

Electrical activities recorded:

Principle:

Give a sound stimulus to the ear and record electrical activity from the promontory (projection of the basal turn of the cochlea). It is done by passing a thin needle electrode through a tympanic membrane and touching the tip of the electrode to the promontory.

There are 2 electrical activities recorded:

  • Summation potential. (SP)
  • Action potential. (AP)

The main thing to be calculated is the SP: AP ratio:

  • *This ratio </=30% is seen in normal people.
  • >30% Indicative of Meniere's disease.
  • >/=45% -Highly suggestive of Meniere's Disease

However, please note that it is only a supportive test, not diagnostic. Meniere's Disease is diagnosed clinically.

Explanation of other options:

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE)(Option A):

  • Measures sounds (echoes) produced by outer hair cells of the cochlea in response to stimuli.
  • Non-invasive, no electrodes inside the ear.
  • Used for newborn hearing screening and to assess cochlear (outer hair cell) function.

Tympanometry(Option B):

  • Measures middle ear pressure and compliance using a probe in the ear canal.
  • Assesses middle ear function (e.g., fluid, eustachian tube dysfunction).
  • Produces a tympanogram, not electrical potentials.

Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA)(Option D):

  • Measures auditory brainstem responses using electrodes placed on the scalp.
  • Assesses the integrity of the auditory nerve and brainstem pathways.
  • Used in diagnosing retrocochlear pathology, like acoustic neuroma.

questions.text: The Tone decay test can be used to detect:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acoustic neuroma is a retrocochlear lesion. Tone decay Test is a measure of auditory nerve fatigue. Tone decay is faster in a retrocochlear lesion.
  • A positive tone decay (significant drop in hearing a continuous tone) strongly suggests damage to the vestibulocochlear nerve, often due to an acoustic neuroma.

Explanation of other options:

Otosclerosis(Option A): A middle-ear (conductive) issue; tone decay would be minimal or negative.

Meniere's disease(Option B): A cochlear/inner-ear disorder; tone decay might show some fatigue but not the nerve-related decline typical of retrocochlear lesions.

Otitis media(Option D): A middle-ear infection; tone decay wouldn't detect this.

questions.text: Which is the diagnostic investigation of choice in assessing hearing loss in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • BERA (brainstem evoked response audiometry) is used to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts.
  • It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain.
  • In this method, electrical potentials are generated in response to several click stimuli or tone bursts and picked up from the vertex by surface electrodes. It measures hearing sensitivity in the range of 1000-4000 Hz.

ABR is used:

  • As a screening procedure for infants.
  • To determine the threshold of hearing in infants, also in children and adults who do not cooperate and in malingerers.
  • To diagnose retrocochlear pathology, particularly acoustic neuroma.
  • To diagnose brainstem pathology, e.g. multiple sclerosis or pontine tumours.
  • To monitor CN VIII intraoperatively in the surgery of acoustic neuromas to preserve the function of the cochlear nerve.

Explanation of other options:

Play Audiometry(Option A):

  • Used in older children (~2.5-5 years)
  • Requires child cooperation
  • Not ideal for infants or very young children
  • More of a screening than a diagnostic tool.

Free Field Audiometry(Option C):

  • Uses speakers in a sound-treated room
  • Depends on the child's response to sound, which is subjective.
  • Not very accurate, can miss unilateral hearing loss

Behavioural Observation Audiometry(Option D):

  • Observes infant's behavioural responses to sounds (eye widening, startle)
  • Very subjective and unreliable
  • Used only in very young infants, but not diagnostic

questions.text: In BERA, wave V is produced by the electrical response from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In BERA, wave V is produced by the electrical response from the Lateral lemniscus.
  • In this method, electrical potentials are generated in response to several click stimuli or tone bursts and picked up from the vertex by surface electrodes.
  • It measures hearing sensitivity in the range of 1000-4000 Hz. In a normal person, seven waves are produced in the first 10 ms.
  • The first, third and fifth waves are most stable and are used in measurements. The waves are studied for absolute latency, interwave latency (usually between wave I and V) and the amplitude.

questions.text: Which audiological finding is true in auditory neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Auditory neuropathy:

Auditory neuropathy(AN) is a variety of hearing loss characterised by a disruption in the transmission of sound from the inner ear to the brain, despite normal function of the outer hair cells in the cochlea.

  • Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE): Reflect outer hair cell function and are typically normal in auditory neuropathy.
  • Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA or ABR): Assesses neural conduction in the auditory pathway; it is abnormal or absent in ANSD due to impaired neural synchrony.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an acoustic finding in auditory neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD), the typical acoustic findings include:

  • Presence of cochlear microphonics (CM): This reflects outer hair cell function, which is usually preserved in ANSD. So, cochlear microphonics are present, not absent. Hence, Option A is not an acoustic finding.
  • Absent stapedial (acoustic) reflexes(Option B ruled out): Due to disrupted neural transmission.
  • Absent or severely abnormal Auditory Brainstem Responses (ABR)(Option C ruled out): Because of neural desynchronization.
  • Absent contralateral suppression of OAE(Option D ruled out): Indicates efferent auditory pathway dysfunction.

questions.text: High-frequency audiometry is used in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ototoxic drugs involve high frequencies more commonly than the low frequencies.
  • High-frequency audiometry tests hearing thresholds above the conventional range (>8000 Hz), often up to 20,000 Hz.
  • Early detection of ototoxicity, as ototoxic drugs (like aminoglycosides, cisplatin) tend to affect high-frequency hearing first, before conventional frequencies are involved.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Otosclerosis(Option B): Typically affects low-frequency hearing; high-frequency audiometry is not particularly useful here.
  • Non-organic hearing loss(Option C): Requires tests like the Stenger test or objective measures (OAE, ABR), not high-frequency audiometry.
  • Meniere's disease(Option D): Characteristically affects low frequencies in early stages.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct interpretation of the given Audiogram
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above audiogram is of the left ear and shows an A-B gap that is suggestive of conductive hearing loss.

  • A typical audiogram measures thresholds at frequencies within a range slightly broader than that of human speech, including 250, 500, 1000, 2000, 3000, 4000, 6000, and 8000 Hz.
  • The primary speech frequencies fall between 500 and 4000 Hz, although normal human hearing ranges from ~20 Hz to ~20,000 Hz.
  • If the bone conduction hearing thresholds are normal, but there is a loss of hearing for air conduction sounds, this is called a conductive hearing loss. This means that the cochlea is normal, but there is some blockage to sound in the middle or outer ears

questions.text: All statements are true about acoustic neuroma except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • BERA shows increased Interaural latency difference of Wave V(Normal 0.2-0.4ms). Hence, Option B is false.
  • Acoustic neuromas are intracranial, extra-axial tumours that arise from the Schwann cells, investing either the vestibular or cochlear nerve.
  • This can often be demonstrated through audiological testing by a phenomenon called "rollover", in which speech discrimination scores decrease as the volume of the speech stimulus increases. A normal score is 80% or greater.
